https://s3.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-us-east/content/pii:S2095495616301942/sc1/HIGHRES/image/jpeg/e0900f9db25733ad862f414000e9ee15/sc1_lrg.jpg sc1 sc1_lrg.jpg jpg 223963 923 2667 IMAGE-HIGH-RES JECHEM 196 S2095-4956(16)30194-2 10.1016/j.jechem.2016.09.007 Science Press Scheme 1 Schematic illustration of the x-BiCF preparation. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 SEM of (a) and (b) 0%-BiCF and (c) and (d) 2%-BiCF; (e) and (f) 2%-BiCF as positive electrode during the first charge process; (g) and (h) 2%-BiCF as negative electrode after 300 cycles. Fig 1 Fig. 2 XRD of x-BiCF (x = 0%, 2%) at different conditions: (1) 0%-BiCF, (2) 2%-BiCF, (3) 2%-BiCF as positive electrode during the first charge process, (4) 2%-BiCF as negative electrode after 300 cycles. Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a) CV curves of 0%-BiCF (curve (1)) and 2%-BiCF (curve (2)) in 0.05M VO2 + + 0.05M VO2+ + 3M H2SO4 solution; CV curve of 0%-BiCF (curve (3)) in 0.05M VO2 + + 0.05M VO2+ + 3M H2SO4 + 0.01M Bi3+ solution. The inset is CV curve of 0%-BiCF in 0.01M Bi3+ + 3M H2SO4 solution. (b) CV curves of x-BiCF (x = 0%, 0.5%, 1%, 2%, 3%, 5%) in 0.05M V3+ + 0.05M V2+ + 3M H2SO4 solution. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Nyquist plots of x-BiCF (x = 0%, 0.5%, 1%, 2%, 3%, 5%) in 0.05M V3+ + 0.05M V2+ + 3M H2SO4 solution at DC voltage of −0.55V in the sweeping frequency range from 106 to 10−2 Hz; the inset is Equivalent circuit for the electrode process. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (a) CE and VE, (b) EE of VFBs assembled with x-BiCF (x = 0%, 0.5%, 1%, 2%, 3%, 5%) as negative electrodes at different charge/discharge current densities varying from 80mA/cm2 to 160mA/cm2, (c) charge/discharge curves at 160mA/cm2, (d) cycling performance of VFBs assembled with 2%-BiCF as negative electrode at 140mA/cm2. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a) Specific discharge capacity and (b) discharge energy density of VFBs at different charge/discharge current densities employing x-BiCF (x = 0%, 2%) as negative electrodes. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Electrochemical performance of VFBs assembled with 2%-BiCF as both positive electrode and negative electrode and only acted as negative electrode: (a) CE and VE, (b) EE, (c) specific discharge capacity and discharge energy density at different current densities, (d) charge/discharge curves at 160mA/cm2. Fig 7 Table 1 Parameters obtained from fitting the impedance plots of x-BiCF (x = 0%, 0.5%, 1%, 2%, 3%, 5%) with the equivalent circuit. Table 1 Sample R s (Ω) R ct (Ω) 0%-BiCF 3.3 280.0 0.5%-BiCF 3.3 118.4 1%-BiCF 3.3 73.6 2%-BiCF 3.3 20.0 3%-BiCF 2.9 86.6 5%-BiCF 2.6 126.0 The catalytic effect of bismuth for VO2 +/VO2+ and V3+/V2+ redox couples in vanadium flow batteries Yang Xiaofei a b Liu Tao a Xu Chi a b Zhang Hongzhang a c * Li Xianfeng a c Zhang Huamin a c * a Division of Energy Storage, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China Division of Energy Storage Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian Liaoning 116023 China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100039, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100039 China c Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemistry for Energy Materials (iChEM), Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemistry for Energy Materials (iChEM) Dalian Liaoning 116023 China * Corresponding author. The effect of bismuth (Bi) for both VO2 +/VO2+ and V3+/V2+ redox couples in vanadium flow batteries (VFBs) has been investigated by directly introducing Bi on the surface of carbon felt (CF). The results show that Bi has no catalytic effect for VO2 +/VO2+ redox couple. During the first charge process, Bi is oxidized to Bi3+ (never return back to Bi metal in the subsequent cycles) due to the low standard redox potential of 0.308V (vs. SHE) for Bi3+/Bi redox couple compared with VO2 +/VO2+ redox couple and Bi3+ exhibit no (or neglectable) electro-catalytic activity. Additionally, the relationship between Bi loading and electrochemical activity for V3+/V2+ redox couple was studied in detail. 2wt% Bi-modified carbon felt (2%-BiCF) exhibits the highest electrochemical activity. Using it as negative electrode, a high energy efficiency (EE) of 79.0% can be achieved at a high current density of 160mA/cm2, which is 5.5% higher than the pristine one. Moreover, the electrolyte utilization ratio is also increased by more than 30%. Even the cell operated at 140mA/cm2 for over 300 cycles, the EE can reach 80.9% without obvious fluctuation and attenuation, suggesting excellent catalytic activity and electrochemical stability in VFBs. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract The roles of bismuth played in vanadium flow battery (VFB) were systemically investigated. The results showed that Bi is promising electro-catalyst for negative reaction but cannot stable on positive side. Keywords Vanadium flow battery Bismuth Catalysis Electrochemical activity Energy efficiency 1 Introduction Recently, energy storage technologies have been playing increasingly important roles in meeting the growing demands of such renewable clean energy as wind power and solar energy for the unsteady and intermittent behavior exhibited during the process of power generation [1–3]. Among them, vanadium flow batteries (VFBs) are considered to be one of the most promising candidates for the merits in decreasing contamination of metal cation by employing same element in both half-cells, where VO2 +/VO2+ and V3+/V2+ serve as the positive electrolyte and the negative electrolyte, as well as it's long life, active thermal management and independence from energy and power ratings [4,5]. Despite the considerable merits, the commercial application process of VFBs, to some extent, is still slowed down by the high material cost of stacks ($/kW). Hence, to search an economic and efficient way to decrease the material cost is the first imperative. Among tremendous methods, to increase the material utilization of VFB stack per kilowatt shows most effective, especially by increasing the operation current (charge and discharge) density on electrodes [6]. By doing this, however, the voltage efficiency of VFB stack is prone to drop sharply, due to the obviously increased electrochemical polarization of the VO2 +/VO2+ and V3+/V2+ redox couples on pristine commercial carbon electrodes. The situation will be worse at even higher current densities, leading to an overall inferior electrochemical performance [7]. As a result, how to improve the electrochemical activity of vanadium redox couples on the electrodes has attracted great attention. For one thing, catalytic activity of the pure carbon fiber electrodes could be enhanced by many methods, such as thermal activation [8,9], acid treatment [10,11], nitrogen-doping [12–15], and electrochemical oxidation [16]. The similar contributions described for these methods are the improvement of hydrophilicity of carbon materials, by introducing oxygenated or nitrogenous groups onto the carbon surface, as well as the increase of active sites for redox reaction of VO2 +/VO2+ and V3+/V2+ [17]. For another thing, to modify the carbon materials with metal and metallic derivation is also an efficient and promising way to enhance electrochemical activity. Wang and Wang [18], have reported that the resistance of the cell assembled with Ir-modified graphite felt as positive electrode was 25% decrease compared with the cell using non-modified one. Meanwhile, a high voltage efficiency of 87.5% was achieved under a current density of 20mA/cm2. However, the high cost is still an obstacle which remains for such noble metals. After that, Tungsten oxide (WO3) was proposed as an alternative for both VO2 +/VO2+ and V3+/V2+ redox couples [19]. Unfortunately, low conductivity evidently exhibited for this kind of material as one of important semiconductor materials. Currently, bismuth (Bi) was proposed as the catalyst of VFBs, with combined merits of low cost, higher electrical conductivity and stiff stability in sulfuric acid solution, compared with Ir [18], CuPt3 [20], WO3 [19], Mn3O4 [21], Nb2O5 [22], and CeO2 [23]. In a recent study, Gonzalez and his co-workers have shown that using Bi-modified graphite felt as the positive electrode presented quite excellent electro-catalytic activity [24]. Nevertheless, after that, more and more reports show the trend that no electro-catalytic activity exhibited for Bi as the positive electrode catalyst [6,25]. Hence, the real role of Bi for the reaction of VO2 +/VO2+ is still uncertain. On the contrary, unlike the competing explanations of the role of Bi for VO2 +/VO2+ redox couple, nearly all of the reports show that Bi can improve the electrochemical activity of negative electrode [6,25,26]. In other words, Bi is a well-suited negative electrode catalyst in VFBs application, especially for the electrode with relatively low electrochemical activity. Hence, further figuring out the relationship between Bi loading and electrochemical activity for V3+/V2+ redox couple is significant. Along this line, a relatively systemic investigation of role of Bi for VO2 +/VO2+ and V3+/V2+ redox couples by introducing Bi on the surface of carbon felt (CF) with traditional high-temperature H2 reduction, is presented in this study. The surface morphology and microstructure of CF and Bi modified carbon felt (BiCF) were investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and scanning electron microscope (SEM). The relationship between Bi loading and electrochemical activity for V3+/V2+ redox couple was discussed by cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). Ultimately, the effect of Bi on the final battery performance was checked by the charge/discharge cycling test. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of Bi-modified electrodes CFs with different Bi loadings were labeled as x-BiCF (x = 0%, 0.5%, 1%, 2%, 3% and 5%, all of value are on the basis of weight), which were obtained by traditional high-temperature H2 reduction method, as illustrated in Scheme 1 . In brief, 0.038g BiCl3 (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) was dissolved in a mixture of 20mL 5wt% HCl and 5mL ethanol; afterward, the mixed solution was impregnated into a piece of prepared CF (Yongdeng industrial felt factory) with a geometrical area of 48cm2. After that, the semi-finished product was dried at 100°C for 8h and thermal treated at 600°C for 2h in a mixture of N2 and H2 (V/V = 5/3). After cooling to room temperature, the obtained product is 1%-BiCF. 2.2 Characterization of Bi-modified electrodes X-ray diffraction (XRD, DX-2700) with Cu Ka radiation (λ = 0.154nm) operated at 40kV and 30mA was used for crystal structure analysis and the XRD dates were collected from 10° to 90° in 2θ at a scanning rate of 1°/min. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JSM-6360LV) using secondary electron (SE) and backscattered electron (BSE) detectors was employed for morphology inspection. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were provided even better insight into the electrochemical activity of x-BiCF. All the tests were operated on a three-electrode system on a CHI604e (CHI instruments, USA) workstation, where x-BiCF filled in a glass carbon electrode with 0.28cm2 effective active area; an area of 12cm2 graphite plate and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) work as the working electrode, the counter electrode, and the conference electrode, respectively. The solution for positive and negative reactions study consists of 0.05M VO2 + + 0.05M VO2+ + 3M H2SO4 solution and 0.05M V3+ + 0.05M V2+ + 3M H2SO4 solution, respectively. EIS curves were obtained by applying an alternating voltage of 5mV over the frequency varying from 106 to 10−2 Hz. The charge/discharge tests were measured on Arbin-BT 2000 instrument (Arbin Co., USA) with a constant current density of 80, 100, 120, 140 and 160mA/cm2. Two pieces of x-BiCF (thickness: 6mm; geometrical area: 48cm2), separated with a piece of Nafion 115 ion exchange membrane (Dupont) were used as the negative and positive electrode. 60mL 1.5M V3+ in 3.0M H2SO4 solution and 60mL 1.5M VO2+ in 3.0M H2SO4 solution, working as negative and positive electrolytes, respectively, were circulated in both sides by two magnetic pumps with a flow rate of 40mL/min. The charge/discharge cutoff voltage was set as 1.55V and 1V. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 SEM survey of Bi-modified electrodes The catalytic effect of Bi for VO2 +/VO2+ and V3+/V2+ redox couples were investigated. Fig. 1 shows the surface morphology of x-BiCF (x = 0%, 2%) at different charge/discharge periods. As shown in Fig. 1(a) and (b), 0%-BiCF is fabricated with large number of carbon fibers with a diameter of nearly 200μm. After 2wt% Bi modified (2%-BiCF), the overall morphology shows no change but some particles whose average size are nearly 50nm except a handful of large particles around 200nm uniformly distributed on the surface of CF, which can be attributed to Bi3+ reduced to Bi under Ar/H2 atmosphere (Fig. 1(c) and (d)). Interestingly, when the 2%-BiCF worked as the positive electrode, during the first charge process, all of the particles disappeared, which can be owed to the low standard redox potential of 0.308V for Bi3+/Bi redox couple compared to VO2 +/VO2+ redox couple and Bi oxidized to soluble Bi3+ in positive electrolyte (Fig. 1(e) and (f)). This output indicates that Bi can't stay on the surface of CF stably and also an unsuitable positive electrode catalyst. On the contrary, using the 2%-BiCF as negative electrode, still a large number of Bi particles remained on the surface of CF even after 300 cycles as shown in Fig. 1(g) and (h), suggesting high stability of Bi on the negative electrode during charge/discharge process. The high stability of Bi can be owed to the enhanced adhesion between CF and catalyst by treating with heat [21]. 3.2 XRD patterns of Bi-modified electrodes In order to further understand the crystal structure of x-BiCF (x = 0%, 2%) at different charge/discharge periods, the relevant XRD patterns were given in Fig. 2. 0%-BiCF only exhibits three characteristic peaks at 24.8°, 43.6° and 78.8°, corresponding to the (002), (100) and (110) planes of carbon, respectively. After Bi modification, two additional peaks located at 37.6° and 39.2°, corresponding to (104) and (110) planes of Bi, suggesting that Bi was successfully anchored onto the surface of CF. The similar XRD pattern to 0%-BiCF and all of peaks corresponding to Bi disappeared using 2%-BiCF as positive electrode during the first charge process, further clarified the poor stability of Bi on the positive electrode. In contrast, the two characteristic peaks of Bi can be still observed when the 2%-BiCF used as negative electrode even after 300 cycles, suggesting that Bi is stable on the negative side during cycling. However, compared to original one (2%-BiCF), the intensity of the peaks became weaker, which can be owed to the alteration of the particles size and crystallinity. All of results are coincided well with the SEM images. 3.3 Electrochemical performance of Bi-modified electrodes To better understand the role of Bi for the reactions of VO2 +/VO2+ and V3+/V2+ redox couples, the electrochemical properties of x-BiCF were investigated by CV measurement as shown in Fig. 3. The CV curves were obtained on the three electrodes system in 0.05M VO2 + + 0.05M VO2+ + 3M H2SO4 solution in the sweeping voltage vary from 0.3V to 1.2V vs. SCE and 0.05M V3+ + 0.05M V2+ + 3M H2SO4 solution in the sweeping voltage vary from −1V to −0V vs. SCE at a scan rate of 10mV/s, respectively. For VO2 +/VO2+ redox couple, as shown in Fig. 3(a), the peaks at approximately 1.1V and 0.6V for both 0%-BiCF and 2%-BiCF electrodes associated with the reaction of VO2+ oxidation and VO2 + reduction, respectively. Similar to previous reports [6,25], compared to the 0%-BiCF, the peak current (i p) and peak potential separation (ΔV) show no change after Bi-modified; this is mainly because Bi is oxidized into Bi3+ with no catalytic activity. From the inset of Fig. 3(a), a couple of peaks located at nearly −0.2V and 0V (vs. SCE) are corresponding to Bi3+ reduction and Bi oxidation. That is to say, before VO2+ transforming into VO2 +, all of Bi was oxidized to soluble Bi3+ in positive electrolyte and never returns back to Bi metal again. This output is consistent well with the SEM and XRD results and also can well-explain why the Bi particles disappeared during the first charge process. Unfortunately, as our speculation, Bi3+ shows no catalytic activity for VO2 +/VO2+ couple, which was further demonstrated by the CV curve with analogical i p and ΔV after adding 0.01M Bi3+ into the positive electrolyte. CV profiles of x-BiCF for V3+/V2+ redox couple are displayed in Fig. 3(b). All of curves show a peak corresponding to V2+ oxidation, while no obviously V3+ reductive peaks can be observed due to the H2 evolution. It is not hard to see that the oxidative peak currents show the trend of first increase and then decrease as the Bi loading increases. Among them, 2%-BiCF shows the biggest oxidative peak current, which is approximately 1.7 times of 0%-BiCF. Moreover, the oxidative peak potential of 2%-BiCF is also more than 0.12V approaching to negative values compared with 0%-BiCF, suggesting the improved electrochemical reversibility. These results can be attributed to the well-dispersed Bi nanoparticles, which play an important role as an electro-catalyst for V3+/V2+ redox couple. The Nyquist plots are given to further understand the improvement of electrode reaction of x-BiCF for V3+/V2+ redox couple. As shown in Fig. 4, nearly each Nyquist plot is consist of an arc at high frequency and a linear part at low frequency, corresponding to charge transfer resistance (R ct) caused by the charge transfer reaction at the electrolyte/electrode interface and the diffusion process of V2+ and V3+ through solution [19,27]. The intersection of arc and the abscissa is ohmic resistance that contains the solution, electrode and contact resistance. The relevant parameters listed in Table 1 were obtained from fitting the impendence plots with the equivalent circuit (the inset of Fig. 4), where R s represents the ohmic solution resistance; CPE and R ct stand for the electric double-layer capacitance of the electrode/solution interface and the charge transfer resistant across the interface, respectively; Z w represents the Warburg impedance due to the diffusion process of vanadium ions [25]. As can be seen, the R ct of all of x-BiCF (x≠0) is smaller than that of 0%-BiCF. Additionally, similar to CV results, the values of R ct also show the first decrease and then increase trend with increasing of Bi loading. 2%-BiCF displays the smallest R ct of 20.0Ω, which is only 1/14 of 0%-BiCF (280.0Ω), meaning the fastest reaction. Therefore, both EIS and CV confirmed that the electrochemical activity of V3+/V2+ redox couple is improved after Bi modification, especially for 2wt% Bi loading. To further understand the catalytic effect of Bi for V3+/V2+ redox couple, the VFBs assembled with x-BiCF as negative electrodes were tested on Arbin-BT 2000 instrument with constant current densities varying from 80mA/cm2 to 160mA/cm2 at 20mA/cm2 intervals. It can be seen from Fig. 5(a), CE exhibits negligible fluctuation around 94.5% at 80mA/cm2, and increases slightly with increasing current density due to the slighter vanadium cross-over. As current density increases, VE decreases significantly for extra polarization voltage [28]. As can be seen, VE first increase and then decrease with increasing Bi loading under the same current density. The highest VE for VFBs with 2%-BiCF as negative electrode is 84.7% at 160mA/cm2, which is increased by 5.8% on the relatively high VE platform of 0%-BiCF. Overall, compared with 0%-BiCF, x-BiCF (x≠0) makes great progress with VE, especially at high current densities. This is mainly attributed to the decreased electrochemical resistance, which can be further proved by the charge/discharge curve with lower charge voltage and higher discharge voltage for 2%-BiCF in Fig. 5(c). EE exhibits the same trend as VE due to the minor change of CE displayed in Fig. 5(b). The VFBs assembled with 2%-BiCF also exhibit the highest EE of 79%, which is 5.5% higher than that of 0%-BiCF. The improvement is neither as large as the ones based on the graphite felt nor negligible based on CF with high activity [6,25]. The phenomenon can be well-explained by our early work that the catalytic effect in VFBs was determined by the proportion of electrochemical impedance in the battery impedance [25]. As is well known, stability is also an important parameter to assess the practicability of catalyst. As reflected in Fig. 5(d), the main performance parameters of VFBs-CE, VE, EE stay around 95.7%, 84.7% and 80.9% at 140mA/cm2 over 300 cycles, respectively, confirming high stability of Bi in the negative electrolyte solution. As previous reports [6,22], the useful voltage window will be reduced with charge/discharge rate increases due to elevating overpotential, leading to the reduction of charge/discharge specific capacity and energy density. Fig. 6(a) and (b) clearly shows that both the specific capacity and energy density show the trend to decrease with increasing current density. However, compared to 0%-BiCF, the specific capacity and energy density of x-BiCF (x≠0) show a relatively moderate attenuation trend due to a reduction of overpotential. Even the current density was increased to 160mA/cm2, a high specific capacity of 22.3Ah/L and high energy density of 26.9Wh/kg can be still maintained for VFBs assembled with 2%-BiCF as negative electrode, which is a large improvement of 30% for 0%-BiCF (specific capacity: 17.0Ah/L; energy density: 19.7Wh/kg). In other words, the fuel utilization ratio was increased by more than 30%, which is significant to decrease the cost of VFBs system. The effect of Bi for VO2 +/VO2+ redox couple was investigated using 2%-BiCF as electrodes for both sides. Fig. 7 clearly exhibits that nearly all of electrochemical parameters (such as CE, VE, EE), specific capacity, specific energy and the charge/discharge curves for VFBs assembled with 2%-BiCF for both sides are similar to the ones that of only assembled with 2%-BiCF as negative electrode. All of results are consistent well with the CV and SEM. Hence, we can deduce that Bi is not a suitable positive catalyst. 4 Conclusions A traditional high-temperature H2 reduction method was used to prepare Bi-modified CF for investigating the effect of Bi for both VO2 +/VO2+ and V3+/V2+ redox couples. Due to the relatively low standard redox potential of Bi3+/Bi redox couple, all of Bi was oxidized to Bi3+ with no electrochemical activity before VO2+ transforming into VO2 +. This is the main reason that causes no catalytic activity of Bi for VO2 +/VO2+ redox couple. In contrast, Bi can significantly improve the electro-catalytic activity of CF for V3+/V2+ redox couple, especially for the Bi loading is 2wt%. The VFBs assembled with 2%-BiCF as negative electrode, a high EE of 79.0% can be obtained at 160mA/cm2. What's more, benefiting from the enhanced adhesion between carbon felt and catalyst by treating with heat, the catalyst shows high stability in the negative electrolyte during long-term charge/discharge process. Even the cell operated at 140mA/cm2 for over 300 cycles, the EE can still reach 80.9% without obvious fluctuation and attenuation. Additionally, the electrolyte utilization ratio is also increased by more than 30%, which is significant for this kind of carbon felt in VFBs application. Acknowledgments The authors greatly acknowledge the financial support from the China Natural Science Foundation (Grant nos. 51403209, 21406221, 21206158, 21476224, 21406219 and 51361135701) and the Outstanding Young Scientist Foundation, Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), Supported by the Key Research Program of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (KG2D-EW-602-2), Science and Technology Service Network Initiative (KFJ-EW-STS-108), Dalian Municipal Outstanding Young Talent Foundation (2014J11JH131). coredata.dc:description: The effect of bismuth (Bi) for both VO2 +/VO2+ and V3+/V2+ redox couples in vanadium flow batteries (VFBs) has been investigated by directly introducing Bi on the surface of carbon felt (CF). The results show that Bi has no catalytic effect for VO2 +/VO2+ redox couple. During the first charge process, Bi is oxidized to Bi3+ (never return back to Bi metal in the subsequent cycles) due to the low standard redox potential of 0.308V (vs. SHE) for Bi3+/Bi redox couple compared with VO2 +/VO2+ redox couple and Bi3+ exhibit no (or neglectable) electro-catalytic activity. Additionally, the relationship between Bi loading and electrochemical activity for V3+/V2+ redox couple was studied in detail. 2wt% Bi-modified carbon felt (2%-BiCF) exhibits the highest electrochemical activity. Using it as negative electrode, a high energy efficiency (EE) of 79.0% can be achieved at a high current density of 160mA/cm2, which is 5.5% higher than the pristine one. Moreover, the electrolyte utilization ratio is also increased by more than 30%. Even the cell operated at 140mA/cm2 for over 300 cycles, the EE can reach 80.9% without obvious fluctuation and attenuation, suggesting excellent catalytic activity and electrochemical stability in VFBs.

coredata.dc:title: The catalytic effect of bismuth for VO2 +/VO2+ and V3+/V2+ redox couples in vanadium flow batteries
